entry.story: One sunny morning, Sparky the orange cat walked in a garden. He saw a buzzing bee, a tall sunflower, a smooth gray rock, and a shiny red watering can. Sparky tilted his head and thought, 'Some of these seem alive, and some don't.'
entry.main_question: Can you tell which one you think is a living thing?

examples: The bee and the sunflower are living things.
I think the flower and bee are alive.
Maybe the bee and the flower?
The rock is not, but the flower is.
The watering can isn't alive, but the bee is.

engagement.story: Sparky watched the bee fly and the sunflower sway. The rock and watering can stayed still. Sparky began to see how living things move and change.
engagement.main_question: What can living things do that non-living things cannot?

examples: Living things can move, grow, and need food or water.
They grow and eat to stay alive.
They can move on their own.

resolution.story: Sparky smiled. He learned that living things move, grow, and need food and water. Non-living things cannot do those things.
resolution.main_question: Can you name one living and one non-living thing you can find at home?

entry.story: Sparky found a small gray rock near the pond. He pushed it with his paw — it rolled a little but stayed still. Beside it, a frog jumped into the water with a splash!
entry.main_question: Which one is living — the rock or the frog?

examples: The frog is alive but the rock is not.
The frog is the living one.

engagement.story: Sparky looked closely. The frog blinked, moved, and swam around. The rock stayed still no matter what he did. Sparky started to see a pattern.
engagement.main_question: How can you tell that the frog is living?

examples: Because it can move, breathe, and grow.
The frog moves and eats, so it's alive.
It's an animal, so it's alive.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that living things like frogs move, grow, and need food and water. Non-living things like rocks do not move on their own or need anything to live.
resolution.main_question: Can you think of another animal that moves like the frog?

entry.story: A gentle breeze blew by as Sparky chased a leaf. The leaf whispered, 'I used to be part of a big tree!' Sparky was surprised — how could a leaf talk?
entry.main_question: Do you think the leaf is still a living thing after it fell?

examples: No, the leaf is not living anymore.
It was living before, but not now.
It used to be alive on the tree.

engagement.story: The leaf explained, 'When I was part of the tree, I helped make food from sunlight. But now that I've fallen, I can't do that anymore.'
engagement.main_question: Why is the leaf not living anymore?

examples: Because it can't grow or make food now.
It's not on the tree, so it stopped living.
It can't make food from the sun.

resolution.story: Sparky understood — living things can stop being alive when they lose what helps them live. He thanked the leaf for teaching him something new.
resolution.main_question: Can you name another thing that was once living but is not anymore?

entry.story: Sparky's tummy rumbled. He looked around for food. A bird nearby was pecking seeds, and a squirrel was nibbling a nut.
entry.main_question: What do you think Sparky, the bird, and the squirrel all need right now?

engagement.story: Sparky found his bowl and started eating. The bird and the squirrel ate too. Their hunger slowly went away.
engagement.main_question: Why do living things need food?

examples: They need food to stay alive.

resolution.story: Sparky felt full and happy. He learned that all living things need food to grow and stay strong.
resolution.main_question: What food helps you grow strong and healthy?

entry.story: Sparky saw a droopy sunflower in the garden. Its leaves were dry and sad. Next to it, another plant stood tall and green.
entry.main_question: Why do you think the first sunflower looks sad?

examples: It's thirsty and didn't get water.

engagement.story: Sparky poured water into the dry soil. The next day, the sunflower perked up, smiling toward the sun again!
engagement.main_question: What helped the plant become healthy again?

resolution.story: Sparky learned that all living things, even plants, need water to live and grow.
resolution.main_question: Can you name one animal that needs water too?

entry.story: Sparky sat under a tree eating his favorite fish snack. A tiny kitten looked at him with hungry eyes.
entry.main_question: What do you think Sparky will do?

examples: Sparky gives some food to the kitten.
He will help the hungry kitten.

engagement.story: Sparky shared half of his snack. The kitten purred happily and started eating right away.
engagement.main_question: Why was the kitten happy after eating?

examples: It got energy from the food.

resolution.story: Sparky realized food helps all living things feel strong and happy. Sharing helps everyone stay healthy.
resolution.main_question: What healthy snack do you like to share?

entry.story: Sparky looked up at a big mango tree. He saw its roots in the soil, a strong trunk, and leaves reaching for the sky.
entry.main_question: Can you name one part of the tree that you can see?

engagement.story: A bird landed on a branch. It pecked at a mango and chirped happily.
engagement.main_question: Which part of the tree holds the bird?

resolution.story: Sparky learned that trees have parts — roots, trunk, branches, leaves, and fruits — that help them grow and live.
resolution.main_question: Can you name another fruit that grows on a tree?

entry.story: Sparky met a lizard who looked worried. 'I lost my tail!' the lizard cried.
entry.main_question: What part of its body did the lizard lose?

engagement.story: Sparky gasped. The lizard smiled, 'Don't worry! My tail will grow back soon.'
engagement.main_question: What can the lizard's tail do that helps it survive?

examples: It helps the lizard escape predators.
It can fall off so the lizard gets away.
It breaks off to trick enemies.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that animals have body parts that help them move, eat, and stay safe — and some can even regrow!
resolution.main_question: What other animal has a tail?

entry.story: Sparky played in the park and saw leaves of different shapes — some round, some pointy, some tiny!
entry.main_question: Do all leaves look the same?

examples: Each leaf is not the same.
They have different shapes and sizes.

engagement.story: Sparky noticed that every leaf is part of a plant. They help the plant make food from sunlight.
engagement.main_question: What do leaves help plants do?

resolution.story: Sparky smiled. Now he knew leaves are special plant parts that help them live and grow.
resolution.main_question: Can you name another part of a plant?

entry.story: Sparky planted a tiny seed in a pot. Every day, he checked it, waiting for something to happen. One morning, a small green sprout popped out of the soil!
entry.main_question: What do you think the seed is doing?

engagement.story: Sparky watered the plant every day. The sprout grew taller and taller, soon with leaves reaching for sunlight.
engagement.main_question: What helped the seed grow into a plant?

examples: Water and sunlight helped it grow.
It grew because Sparky took care of it.

resolution.story: Sparky smiled proudly at his growing plant. He learned that all living things grow and change as they live.
resolution.main_question: Can you name something else that grows over time?

entry.story: Sparky visited his friend's house and met a tiny puppy named Max. Max was small enough to fit in a basket!
entry.main_question: What do you think will happen to Max as time passes?

examples: He will become a big dog.

engagement.story: After a few weeks, Sparky visited again. Max was taller and stronger, running and barking happily.
engagement.main_question: What changed about Max?

examples: He's not a tiny puppy anymore.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that animals, like people and plants, grow as they get older.
resolution.main_question: Can you name one way you have grown?

entry.story: Sparky saw a small tadpole swimming in a pond. It had no legs, just a tiny tail.
entry.main_question: Do you know what this tadpole will grow into?

examples: It will grow into a frog.

engagement.story: Weeks later, Sparky returned. The tadpole had grown legs and could jump out of the water!
engagement.main_question: What changed about the tadpole?

examples: It grew legs and became a frog.
Its tail got smaller and it grew legs.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that living things grow and change as part of life — even tiny tadpoles become frogs one day.
resolution.main_question: Can you think of another animal that changes as it grows?

entry.story: One afternoon, Sparky walked on the road. The pavement was hot! He quickly moved to the shade under a tree.
entry.main_question: Why did Sparky move to the shade?

examples: The sun made the ground hot.

engagement.story: Sparky rested under the tree, feeling better. He noticed birds flying away from the sun too.
engagement.main_question: What did Sparky and the birds both do?

examples: They both moved to cooler places.
They got out of the hot sun.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that living things respond to what they feel — like moving when it's too hot or cold.
resolution.main_question: What do you do when you feel too hot?

entry.story: Sparky saw some flowers in the garden. They were open and bright in the morning, but at night, they closed their petals.
entry.main_question: Why do you think the flowers close at night?

engagement.story: In the morning, the flowers opened again, facing the sun. They seemed happy and ready for the new day!
engagement.main_question: What makes the flowers open again?

resolution.story: Sparky learned that plants also respond to changes around them, just like animals do.
resolution.main_question: Can you name another living thing that reacts to light or sound?

entry.story: Sparky heard a rustle in the bushes. A rabbit jumped out, then quickly ran away when it saw him!
entry.main_question: Why did the rabbit run away?

engagement.story: Sparky waited quietly, and the rabbit came back when it felt safe.
engagement.main_question: How did the rabbit know it was safe to return?

examples: It saw there was no danger.

resolution.story: Sparky realized that animals respond to danger by running or hiding to stay safe.
resolution.main_question: What do you do when you feel scared?

entry.story: Sparky looked up and saw a bird's nest. Inside were tiny baby birds chirping loudly while their mother brought food.
entry.main_question: Where do you think the baby birds came from?

engagement.story: The mother bird fed the chicks until they grew feathers and learned to fly.
engagement.main_question: What is the mother bird doing for her babies?

resolution.story: Sparky learned that living things have babies to continue their kind — like birds hatching eggs or cats having kittens.
resolution.main_question: Can you name another animal that lays eggs?

entry.story: Sparky visited his friend's house and saw their dog had puppies! They were small, soft, and always sleeping.
entry.main_question: What did the mother dog do to have puppies?

engagement.story: The puppies grew day by day, opening their eyes and learning to walk.
engagement.main_question: What happens to the puppies as they grow?

resolution.story: Sparky realized that all living things reproduce so there are more of their kind.
resolution.main_question: Can you name a baby animal you know?

entry.story: Sparky found tiny seeds inside a red apple. He wondered, 'What are these for?'
entry.main_question: What do you think seeds can grow into?

engagement.story: Sparky planted the seeds and watered them every day. Soon, little sprouts appeared.
engagement.main_question: What helped the seeds grow?

resolution.story: Sparky learned that plants make seeds to grow new plants — that's how they reproduce.
resolution.main_question: Can you think of another fruit that has seeds?

stories.title: The Lost Dodo
stories.topic: Characteristics of Living Things - Survival & Extinction

entry.story: Sparky read about a bird called the dodo. It used to live on an island but doesn't exist anymore.
entry.main_question: What do we call it when a kind of animal no longer exists?

examples: It means they are gone forever.

engagement.story: Sparky learned that people hunted the dodo and destroyed its home. Without food and shelter, the dodo couldn't survive.
engagement.main_question: Why did the dodo become extinct?

examples: They lost their homes and food.
They had no place to live.

resolution.story: Sparky felt sad but learned that protecting animals and their homes helps them survive.
resolution.main_question: Can you name an animal that we should help protect?

stories.title: The Clever Turtles
stories.topic: Characteristics of Living Things - Survival & Extinction

entry.story: Sparky visited the beach and saw baby turtles hurrying to the sea. They had to move fast before the sun got too hot!
entry.main_question: Why do the baby turtles need to reach the sea quickly?

examples: Because it's too hot and dangerous.
To be safe in the water.
They need to get to the water.

engagement.story: Sparky cheered as the last turtle reached the water. The waves carried them safely away.
engagement.main_question: How does the sea help the turtles survive?

examples: It's their home and has food.
It keeps them safe from birds.
They can swim and live in the water.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that animals survive by finding food and safe places to live.
resolution.main_question: Can you name a place where animals live safely?

stories.title: The Forest Helpers
stories.topic: Characteristics of Living Things - Survival & Extinction

entry.story: Sparky and his friends saw a forest being cut down. Birds and monkeys had no place to live!
entry.main_question: What will happen to animals if they lose their homes?

examples: They might die or move away.
They will have nowhere to live.
They might get hurt or die.

engagement.story: Sparky and his friends planted new trees to give the animals a home again.
engagement.main_question: How did Sparky help the animals survive?

examples: By planting trees, he gave them a new home.
He helped make a new forest.

resolution.story: Sparky learned that living things need food, water, and shelter to survive — and we can help them too.
resolution.main_question: What can you do to help animals or plants survive?
